name: Clorazepate (Tranxene)
summary: A long-acting benzodiazepine used for anxiety disorders, acute alcohol withdrawal, and as an adjunct in seizure disorders.
description: Clorazepate is a benzodiazepine prodrug that is rapidly converted in the stomach to the active metabolite desmethyldiazepam (nordiazepam). It exerts anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, and anticonvulsant effects through potentiation of GABA-A receptor activity. Its long half-life makes it suitable for continuous symptom control but may lead to accumulation with prolonged use.

sections.text: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening, leading to CNS depression. Clorazepate is a prodrug rapidly converted to desmethyldiazepam.

adult.alcohol-withdrawal: 30–90 mg/day in divided doses for 3–7 days
adult.seizure-adjunct: Up to 90 mg/day in divided doses

sections.geriatric: Start at lower doses (7.5–15 mg/day) due to prolonged half-life
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use caution; risk of drug accumulation

items: Tablets: 3.75 mg, 7.5 mg, 15 mg, 22.5 mg, 30 mg

sections.text: Onset within 30–60 minutes; long half-life (30–200 hours for active metabolite) provides sustained effect.

sections.black_box: Concomitant use with opioids may result in profound sedation, respiratory depression, coma, and death.
other: Risk of dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal
Elderly more susceptible to sedation, confusion, and falls
May impair driving or operating machinery

items: Signs of sedation and respiratory depression

sections.pregnancy: Category D; avoid unless benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; avoid or monitor infant for sedation
sections.pediatrics: Not generally recommended for anxiety; may be used for seizures with caution
sections.geriatrics: Lower doses recommended due to increased sensitivity

sections.text: Reduce gradually over weeks to prevent withdrawal symptoms, especially after long-term use.

items: Particularly useful when a long-acting benzodiazepine is desired
Metabolized to desmethyldiazepam, which has a long half-life
Often chosen in alcohol withdrawal protocols for smooth coverage
